body: See https://github.com/confluentinc/examples/issues/76#issuecomment-256351432
LGTM.
Merged to trunk.

@hachikuji Could you please take a look at this PR and let me know if you can think of a better way to handle this case? Thanks.

Update: I believe the failing regression test `org.apache.kafka.streams.integration.ResetIntegrationTest.testReprocessingFromScratchAfterReset` in some of the recent builds could be related to the issue addresses here.

Ping @junrao @ijuma. Previous serialization of the request/response objects depended on serializing the struct representation directly into a `ByteBuffer`. Because `FetchResponse` needs to write to the channel directly (to support "zero copy"), I modified these objects to instead provide their own `Send` objects, which allowed me to override the default send behavior. I also implemented a custom `Records` schema type to make the usage a little nicer.

To interoperate with the server-side `MessageSet` objects, I added a method to convert to the `Records` representation. Internally, the server still uses `MessageSet`, but it converts to `Records` prior to serialization, which allowed me to get rid of `MessageSet.writeTo`.
LGTM. Do we need to adjust the zk session timeout as well or do you think this is only affecting the initial connection?
Build failed in know unstable test. Will trigger new build.
I wondered about that, but since I haven't yet seen failures due to the session timeout, I didn't change it.
@guozhangwang Can you do a final review an merge if you approve?
Comments addressed.
Having fun reviewing it, @junrao @ijuma hope you enjoy as well :)
Nice one. Haven't reviewed yet, but just wanted to mention that we should probably file a JIRA about consolidating the `MessageSet` classes with the `Record` classes.

@junrao Will you be able to take a look? I am thinking if we should have a better configuration compatibility check in the configurations. Currently we have a `Recommender` in the ConfigDef, but that seems not sufficient because it only gives a set of valid values of a configuration based on the value of some other configuration. In many cases we only want to verify wether the values user provided for different configurations make sense or not. So we just need something like a compatibility validator. We can probably do that in another patch. What do you think?
LGTM
LGTM, modulo Guozhang's comment. My main comment (see inline) shouldn't hold this back.
Ok, this is a fairly big change, could we also report on 1) whether system tests pass and 2) whether the Interactive Queries demos still run. I can help with either or both, just let me know.
The failure seems to be the recurring one from resetting, not related to this.
@ijuma Makes sense. I'll go ahead and merge this.

@mimaison Thanks for the patch. I think raising an exception when the offset is negative makes total sense, but I wonder if we should be a bit more conservative about the other case since it is a backwards incompatible change. Also, one of the unfortunate side effects of calling `updatePositions` is that `commitAsync` can now block. I'm probably a little inclined to leave the behavior as it is or do a short KIP to get some wider feedback. What do you think?
thanks @enothereska , as for the IQ demos are you referring to the confluentinc/examples? I did make a quick run on those and do not see any failures.
@guozhangwang yes. Then just the streams smoke test and bounce test is left.

I'd prefer to observe the jenkins builds after the PR is merged and if there are errors we can file follow-up PRs. Generally we only pre-check system tests for new features / architectural changes and I feel this PR is none of these, given it is a bit long.
@ijuma Thanks for the review. I'd appreciate another look when you get a chance.
LGTM. Thanks for the patch.
@joestein please help review this. Thanks.
Review by @hachikuji
Thanks for the PR, LGTM.

Thanks for the PR. A couple of things:
1. This could break existing users, so we need to decide if we're OK with that. Probably worth starting a mailing list thread to get wider input. If we go ahead, we should add a note to the upgrade notes so that users are aware of the change.
2. There should be tests to verify the change.
That's a fair point, if we already document it like that, then it's just a bug fix. Let's add a note to the upgrade notes still though (`upgrade.html`).
@ijuma Please guide what I should do next. I am a freshman to the process. Thanks.

@guozhangwang turns out I had a bit of logging going on. With no logging the numbers from 5 runs of shouldCorrectlyRepartitionOnJoinOperations are:
- with shutdown: 22, 22, 22, 21, 21 seconds (avg 21.6)
- with suspend:   17, 17, 15, 14, 14 seconds (avg 15.4)

So that's around 28% improvement.

@ijuma Can you provide some more detail on which test is failing? Everything seems ok when I run locally here. The fix itself looks correct, but I'm a little puzzled why it matters since the test doesn't appear to use the port anywhere.

Thanks @enothereska the improvement looks significant for the worthwhileness of the optimization. Could we close / reopen this PR to let Jenkins trigger another build since the reported errors are new to me but I cannot reproduce it locally.
@mjsax @hachikuji comments addressed.
@guozhangwang there is definitely a bug there and we shouldn't merge until it's fixed. Still chasing, it's tricky to reproduce.

@hachikuji This PR also fixes another issue that was introduced by the fix for KAFKA-3144. I point to it inline. Let me know if you think that issue should be fixed and merged (more quickly) in a separate PR. Thanks.

@guozhangwang @enothereska @dguy @miguno 

Should we add a test, too?

@hachikuji Comments addressed; about extracting a couple for loops into separate functions: personally I'm a bit inclined not to do it if it is only called once, and the procedure itself do not have significant semantic meaning except construct some data structure from other structures.
System tests (smoke and bounce tests) passed.
@guozhangwang Fair enough. I just noticed there was a lot of boilerplate conversion in this code between different objects and maps. It adds a lot of noise to the overflow flow.
Unrelated jenkins environment failure
LGTM
Same jenkins failure. Looks like something is wrong with Jenkins.
@guozhangwang @ijuma
@enothereska Could you try retrigger jenkins again? https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2012 's jenkins succeeded.
@guozhangwang worked, thanks.
@mjsax a test would be nice.
Merged to trunk.
Could you rebase as well?
KStreamAggregationIntegrationTest > shouldGroupByKey[1] FAILED I haven't seen this failure before, will need investigating.

I opened a JIRA for this one (https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/KAFKA-4359), it's not related to this PR and I'll need to clean up multiple tests. Will also commit a fix just for shouldGroupByKey for this PR.
@enothereska @miguno @guozhangwang Updated.
@guozhangwang @enothereska Updated.
Failure in Kafka unrelated to PR, but stopped rest of tests.

I get the following failures:

LGTM

There is a potential issue that table-table-join resulted table does not have the `storeName`, and hence the following topology will cause throw exceptions:

```
stream.join(table1.join(table2))
```

on

```
topology.connectProcessorAndStateStores(name, other.getStoreName());
```

in `KStreamImpl`. @mjsax could you file another JIRA to keep track of it?

As for the solution, I think we may still need to materialize the KTable on-the-fly if the above scenario happens and `other.getStoreName()` returns null indicating that this KTable is not materialized yet.

LGTM. Thanks for the patch! I'm going to run some system tests prior to merging to make sure we didn't miss anything obvious, but hopefully we can wrap this up shortly.

I have a bit of concern of having a `values` method since it requires adding a new first-citizen interface class (as suggested in https://github.com/apache/kafka/compare/trunk...xvrl:kstreams-kvaluestream?expand=1) to the DSL API. Personally I'd suggest we do not need to mimic Scala style in the Java APIs, but we could consider having a slight different set of function when we add the Scala APIs in the future that is closer to the Scala syntax.
`values` is actually present in java.util.Map since before Scala existed so I am not sure why it would be mimicking the Scala API.

You are right, forget about the `mimicking` stuff I mentioned above. I think my concern is mainly boiled down to whether it is worthwhile having a first-class  `KValueStream` interface which is a stream of values only. To me the benefits is that we can have some syntax convenience since users do not need to specify the dummy key in the operator apply function / lambda expression in the future, but the disadvantage is that once you reduced it to value streams only, you cannot enhance it back to a key-value paired stream, and hence in the end when you write it down to the sink topic, you have to choose either omitting the keys, i.e. put them as nulls indicating that keys are not important, or still print the keys as inherited from the original key-value paired stream which is opaque to programmers.

@guozhangwang in the suggested implementation in https://github.com/apache/kafka/compare/trunk...xvrl:kstreams-kvaluestream?expand=1 I actually allow to enhance it back to the underlying key value stream. In that sense it's not really a different stream type but just a thin wrapper around the existing stream, leaving the possibility of course to optimize things under the hood to avoid key serde if necessary.

@hachikuji This is the PR for the bug we discussed (under [PR for KAFKA-3853](https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/2074)) on Friday. Would appreciate your feedback, and opinion about the comment by @harshach. Thanks.

@guozhangwang can you say any more about the impact of a new first-class interface? 

The main issue I see with introducing `KValueStream` is that it's not clear what you should get after doing something like `stream.values.map(handler::doIt).through("topic")`.  Did you
a) convert stream from a `KStream` to a `KValueStream` without pulling the keys back and now all keys should be null?
b) use `KValueStream` as syntactic sugar and expect the keys are preserved?

I guess I'm leaning toward the existing API b/c it seems more explicit.

@dguy I left a comment about the `CachingKeyValueStore.delete()` function, which I am not sure could be causing the `IllegalStateException` (if it is purely written in DSL I think it should not be the cause as the `delete` function seems not called at all), and I'm wondering if itself is a bug.

To me the `KValueStream`'s benefits are for syntactic sugar only, but it introduces quite some complexity in the programming model which may overwhelm its benefits (thinking about how we need to write docs for this feature). For example:

I as a user have a few operators like `mapValues` and `foreachValues` function in the middle of my topology, and now I want to transform them into `values` followed by `map` and `foreach`, and then later in my topology when I wanted to call any other functions that are not `xxValues` I need to call `entries` to get the KStream again, this syntax is a bit different from Java syntax where if you call `values` you are effectively "projecting" only the values in the future operations, and cannot go back; even if I am OK with that, I still need to be careful about operators that is not a one-to-one mapping (e.g. `flatMap`) where in this case the before-projectiong `KStream` is actually inheriting the same key for each of the output when you transform back via `entries`.

So personally I'd prefer to keep the programming model enforcing users to think about these corner issues themselves, i.e. to make the API simple-to-reason though maybe less convienent.
